                    ### Question
                    A three year old child is brought to the emergency depament having just ingested a large overdose of an antihistaminic drug. This drug is a weak base capable of entering most tissues including the brain. On physical examination the hea rate is 100/ minute, blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg and the respiratory rate is 20/ minute. In this case of poisoning:

                    ### Options
                    opa. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent
opb. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NaHCO 3, an alkalinizing agent
opc. More of the drug would be ionized at blood pH than at stomach pH
opd. Absorption of the drug would be faster from the stomach than from the small intestine.

### Enhanced Information (For Contextual Support):
In cases of poisoning with a weak base antihistaminic drug, urinary excretion can be influenced by urine pH. Administering NH4Cl, an acidifying agent, would lower urine pH, increasing the ionization of the drug in urine and thereby accelerating its excretion. Conversely, administering NaHCO3, an alkalinizing agent, would raise urine pH, leading to decreased ionization and slower excretion of the drug. Regarding absorption, weak bases are more non-ionized in acidic environments, such as the stomach, compared to the more neutral pH of the small intestine, which facilitates greater absorption in the stomach. Therefore, the correct reasoning aligns with the option stating that urinary excretion would be accelerated by NH4Cl administration, while the option regarding NaHCO3 is incorrect as it would slow excretion. The statements about ionization at different pH levels are accurate, confirming that more of the drug would be non-ionized in the stomach than in the small intestine.
